awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Vehicle Lane-Keeping Through Pavement-Assisted Passive Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that seeks to enhance road safety for drivers and prevent future accidents by limiting vehicle lane departures because of distracted or impaired drivers. This technology also reduces lane departures and accidents in adverse weather conditions when drivers or lane-keeping technologies fail because they cannot see the edges of the lanes. The proposed activity may lead to more rapid adoption of advanced driver-assistance systems and autonomous vehicles in the future.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of continuous electromagnetic (EM) signatures within or on top of paving materials (asphalt or concrete) to complement existing vehicle lane-keeping capabilities.  The technology will enable better vehicle-to-pavement passive communication in normal and adverse weather conditions. The EM signature is created by embedding small amounts of metallic materials into the existing pavement materials at specific lateral locations thereby changing the magnetic permeability of the target location. By changing the lateral magnetic properties in the lane, inexpensive vehicle sensors can detect their lateral position with significant accuracy. This technology may be applied during new roadway construction or during the repair of existing roadways and can function in any type of weather conditions. Since improvements in vehicle safety require knowing and maintaining the vehicle position within the lane, the innovation can significantly reduce lane departures that lead to fatal accidents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Vehicle lane departures are one of the major causes of fatal crashes on roadways. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) reported that from 2015 to 2019, 50% of all the fatal crashes were associated with vehicle lane departure and this increased to 75% during adverse weather conditions. Advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS) technologies should provide drivers and roadway agencies with significantly higher roadway safety against lane departures than the currently adopted strategies such as lower maximum speeds, stricter enforcement, or geometric changes to the roadway. One challenge with ADAS is that lane departure warning is not currently possible in adverse weather conditions such as intense rainfall, snow, fog, and icing, when lane markings or edge of pavement are not visible. The core technology we have developed in university research is to minimize vehicle lane departures in all weather conditions on roadways, which lowers accident risks and professional liability for road safety engineers at Department of Transportations. The adoption will significantly increase vehicle driver safety by reducing severe injuries and fatalities up to 60%, especially in adverse weather conditions. The proposed technology identified for commercialization under NSF I-Corps training places a continuous electromagnetic (EM) signature within the roadway surface to complement existing vehicle lane-keeping capabilities based only on camera-based vision and vehicle control algorithms.

The proposed V2I technology has potential to greatly enhance the road safety for drivers and prevent many future accidents from occurring by limiting vehicle lane departures because of errant, distracted, or impaired drivers. The commercial adoption and impact of this technology will be enormous given there are over 5 million miles of roadways in the USA and 200 million drivers. The proposed activity will further advance V2I communication that will allow a more rapid adoption of ADAS in the future.

The I-Corps customer discovery interviews determined that most customers were not that familiar of how advanced driver assist systems (ADAS) functioned and therefore, they had insufficient knowledge of problems with current ADAS and lane keeping especially in adverse weather conditions. Thus, the V2I technology as proposed initially was not a great product market fit at this time. To keep moving forward with our current V2I ideas, the customer interviews discovered multiple stakeholders were interested in improving the safety of construction work zones and we could have a higher set of first adopters and less complex ecosystem if we could temporarily pivot from lane keeping to driver safety warnings in construction work zones using coded messages in the pavement. Secondly, we decided to spend more time on finding an agency partner that could pilot a lane departure warning demonstration on a test road or section of roadway to show its capabilities. Therefore, we concluded that we must continue conducting additional university research on lane departure warning with passive material sensors to expand the knowledge of the key benefits and issues with ADAS, educate key stakeholders, and further develop the research for the pivot idea on construction work zones.

The key outcomes of this NSF I-Corps project were to immediately pivot research efforts on using idea of passive materials sensing for lane keeping to warn drivers in construction work zones of their speeds and vehicle maneuvering actions like merging, upcoming entrances and exit ramps, and upcoming lane closures and thus protect construction workers and drivers simultaneously. Additionally, a pilot project and first adopter need to be identified and secured within a state DOT to demonstrate the lane departure warning system or construction work zone communication on a real vehicle and roadway segment. Both the pivot research on construction work zones will improve safety of drivers through work zones and on-site construction workers and a pilot project on the V2I lane departure warning will enable significant accident and fatalities reductions on roadways which will tremendously impact the negative social and economic costs because of vehicular accidents.
